Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Cross-disciplinary Education in Social & Ethical Aspects of Nanotechnology

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: Cross-disciplinary Education in Social & Ethical Aspects of Nanotechnology", at Arizona State University, under the direction of Dr. Thomas P. Seager, will develop a unique four weeks long workshop experience for undergraduate students that will explore the social and ethical issues raised by nanotechnology, build cross-disciplinary communicative competence, and enhance engineering leadership and teamwork skills. Three objectives will be achieved by adapting learning activities originally developed by the LEGO Group called Lego Serious Play (LSP, www.seriousplay.com), an open source, facilitated workshop method that allows for material deliberation. Participants in LSP workshops explore challenges related to an ongoing project, task, or strategy by building symbolic and metaphorical models of their insights in LEGO bricks and presenting them to each other. This workshop will address the difficult aspect of cross disciplinary communication in an interactive setting that plans to bring together science/engineering and social science majors.

This NUE program will directly provide training to a diverse cohort of faculty and undergraduate students, and a PhD student in the Herberger Institute of Design with expertise in LSP. It will advance the understanding of the processes by which students can acquire communicative competence outside their primary field of practice and enhance teamwork, leadership, and understanding of social issues in engineering students, while improving nanotechnology literacy in non-engineering students. The program will specially reach out to underrepresented groups within engineering. Lastly, the project will leverage technical work and products from a prior NUE award at ASU, produce and disseminate a series of two-minute videos that document the workshop experience from the undergraduate student experience, and produce a longer "Faculty Cross Talk" under the auspices of the ASU Office of Institutional Inclusion that documents the faculty experience, and provides source materials to other Universities seeking to replicate the successful aspects of the program's approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cross-disciplinary Education in Social & Ethical Aspects of Nanotechnology Project at Arizona State University (ASU) deepened student understanding of nanotechnology’s social, ethical, and environmental issues and strengthened engineering education outcomes related to communication, teamwork, leadership, and lifelong learning. The project developed and implemented a multi-week workshop experience for science, engineering and social science undergraduate students. Through the “Nano Ethics at Play” (NEAP) workshop series, students explored the social, ethical, and environmental issues raised by nanotechnology, built cross-disciplinary communicative competence, and enhanced leadership and teamwork skills using Lego Serious Play activities (LSP; www.seriousplay.com).

Activities:

- The program team developed a workshop model that included undergraduate educational and faculty development materials regarding nanotechnology and is social and ethical implications.

- Faculty and graduate students were trained in cross-disciplinary communication facilitation, tools, and activities using Lego Serious Play (LSP) to advance their own understanding of interdisciplinary communication skills.

- The project team piloted two workshops in the fall semester, collected participant insights into the workshops’ effectiveness and recommendations for strengthening the program and integrated changes into the final iteration of the workshop series.

  • Participants engaged in five 3-hour workshop sessions: Lego-Serious Play Skill Building, Nano-related Applications and Implications, Expert Opinions and Social Justice Issues, Conation for Teamwork, and Nano-applications in Photovoltaics
  • Students learned from nanotechnology experts thru lectures. They then used Legos to represent their individual insights and perspectives regarding the topic in story form (storytelling), accounting for social, ethical, and environmental considerations. In some sessions, participants were asked to integrate aspects of their individual models into team models and convey the outcomes to the larger group—e.g. recommendations for governing Nano-related technologies.

- Graduate students mentored undergraduates during workshop sessions and the course, analyzed results, collaborated on written research products, and presented at conferences, PI meetings, and conducted workshops outside of the university.

Outcomes:

The NEAP workshops brought undergraduate students and faculty from multiple disciplines together to explore nanotechnology and its impacts using Legos. The workshops supported cross-disciplinary communication that focused on ideation, knowledge-sharing, and perspective-taking. This provided engineering students with the tools to communicate effectively outside their primary discipline, helping them acquire nanotechnology social, ethical and environmental knowledge from other disciplines. In addition, students from other disciplines gained knowledge of nanoscience and engineering. This LSP-based knowledge sharing provided all participants with an educational foundation from which interactional expertise (IE) can be built. It also enables the students to contribute as STEM-literate citizens.

Specific Project Outcomes:

- Year 1: two graduate assistants were certified as LSP faciliators. Another graduate student assisted with qualitative assessment of communications skills. A part-time undergraduate assistant was trained in developing and testing workshop activities and assessments.

- Year 2: one undergraduate student was trained as an LSP facilitator.

- Year 3: two undergraduate research advisees completed BS degrees in Civil Engineering. Three supplemental awards supported research experiences for two undergraduates and two community college teachers. Four veterans received direct training in literature search and critical review, and communicating science. One completed training in the Lego Serious Play facilitation method.

- Additionally, the project supported the professional development of several graduate students, two of whom have completed their MS and PhD degrees.

Specific Course Outcomes:

Pre- and post-course surveys on student “confidence in communication and collaboration” showed that the course increased students’ ability to:

  • Communicate their ideas about complex issues to individuals outside their major - 77% to 96% (“pretty” and “very” confident);
  • Form new ways of thinking about complex issues – 78% to 100%
  • Work collaboratively to explore complex issues – 94% to 100% 

- All students either “agreed” or “strongly agreed” that the LSP activities a) increased understanding of their personal learning style, b) increased their ability to explain their ideas, and c) made it easier to understand the ideas of team members. A majority of students (71%) did find LSP challenging to use for expressing themselves.

- All students “agreed” or “strongly agreed” that a) they valued the perspectives of team members from other disciplines, b) they felt actively engaged in the course, and c) the course exceeded expectations. 83% of the students admitted that the course forced them outside of their comfort zone.

- 94% of students (17 out of 18) would recommend the course to others; 47% (8 out of 17) liked learning about perspectives from and working with students in other disciplines; and 41% of respondents liked the challenge LSP presented and found using it fun.

Students clearly articulated an increased understanding of what nanotechnology was as well as its social and ethical implications.
